presentation.title: Sediment regulation: Delivery of beneficial sediment to farmers or avoided undesirable sedimentation of farmland
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from sediment regulation by ecosystems in providing beneficial or detrimental sediment to floodplain farmland.
presentation.description: Values resulting from erosion prevention and natural sediment deposition by ecosystems, and accounting for the delivery of beneficial sediment or the prevention of detrimental sedimentation to farmland. Flow models are used to attribute beneficial or detrimental sources of sediment or "sinks" that promote sediment deposition in relation to their human beneficiaries.

page.name: Assessment of farmland susceptible to sediment deposition
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This model considers floodplain farmland as a potential beneficiary of sediment regulation. Depending on the crops and timing of sedimentation, this process can be beneficial, delivering new fertile sediment, or detrimental, causing crop damage. These models map flows from sediment sources (areas of erosion), sinks (areas where deposition occurs), and beneficiary groups and link these via a flow model accounting for the downstream movement of sediment. To map farms susceptible to sedimentation, we simply intersect farmland with floodplain extents data.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Hydrologic soils group
page.title: Hydrologic soils group
page.description:
Different soil types have different infiltration capacities. See http://www.ems-i.com/wmshelp/Hydrologic_Models/Calculators/Composite_Runoff_Coefficients/Selecting_the_Method.htm.

Role in models

Soils are classified from group A (highest infiltraiton capacity) to D (lowest infiltration capacity); group accounts for maximum yearly wetness, degree of soil freezing, bare soil surface, and swelling of clays, but does not account for slope. We use HSG along with slope, slope stability, and soil texture data to estimate soil erodibility in ad hoc erosion models. We assume greater erodibility in soils with higher infiltration capacity.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

SSURGO soils data (U.S.); University of Vermont Spatial Analysis Lab, derived from FAO soils data (global).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: USDA-NRCS SSURGO soils database.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Slope
page.title: Slope
page.description:
Slope strongly affects potential erosion by influencing slope stability and runoff speed.

Role in models

Since hydrologic soils group classifications do not account for slope, we use slope along with hydrologic soils group, slope stability, and soil texture data to estimate soil erodibility in ad hoc erosion models. Greater erodibility is assumed on steep slopes where runoff occurs quickly.

Representation

The data are in physical units of degrees slope.

Source

Data are derived from a global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Derived from Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Slope stability
page.title: Slope stability
page.description:
A classification of the mechanical stability of slopes.

Role in models

Slope stability data, where available, can be used to probabilistically estimate soil erodibility. Unstable slopes are particularly prone to erosion.

Representation

The data are categorical.

Source

Washington State Department of Natural Resources.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Washington State DNR.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil texture
page.title: Soil texture
page.description:
Soil texture can influence its erodibility.

Role in models

Soil texture data can be used to probabilistically estimate soil erodibility. We assume greater erodibility for finer-textued soils.

Representation

The data are categorical.

Source

SSURGO soils data (U.S.); FAO soils data (global).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: USDA-NRCS SSURGO soils database, FAO Global Soils database.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Soil erodibility
page.title: Soil erodibility
page.description:
Soil erodibility coefficients used in the Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation.

Role in models

Soil erodibility estimates can either be directly used to estimate erosion using RUSLE or can be used to train Bayesian networks when using ad hoc probabilistic models of erosion in cases where RUSLE's use is inappropriate.

Representation

The data are unitless estimates of erodibility used in the Revised Universal Soil Loss Equation.

Source

U.S. EPA EMAP-West Metric Browser (U.S.); Yang, D., et al. 2003. Global potential soil erosion with reference to land use and climate changes. Hydrological Processes 17: 2913-2928 (global).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: U.S. EPA EMAP-West Metric Browser, Yang et al. (2003).
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual precipitation
page.title: Annual precipitation
page.description:
Annual precipitation.

Role in models

Precipitation data are used along with soil erodiblity and vegetative maturity to estimate overall erosion in the ad hoc erosion source models. In regions susceptible to tropical storms and with steep slopes, tropical storm probability is included as an influence on runoff, with annual precipitation, since these extreme storm events can cause larger event-based episodes of erosion.

Representation

The data are in physical units of millimeters of precipitation per year.

Source

PRISM Climate Group (U.S. data); WorldClim (global data).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: WorldClim, PRISM
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Tropical storm probability
page.title: Tropical storm probability
page.description:
Deciles estimates of tropical storm risk.

Role in models

In regions susceptible to tropical storms and with steep slopes, tropical storm probability is included with annual precipitation as an influence on runoff, since these extreme storm events can cause larger event-based episodes of erosion. Runoff estimates are then used along with soil erodiblity and vegetative maturity to estimate overall erosion in the ad hoc erosion source models

Representation

The data are in deciles of tropical storm risk.

Source

CIESIN Hazards Data.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: CIESIN Hazards data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual runoff
page.title: Annual runoff
page.description:
Runoff as used to estimate soil erosion, along with soil and vegetation characteristics.

Role in models

Runoff estimates can be used to train Bayesian networks when using ad hoc probabilistic models of erosion.

Representation

The data are physical units of millimeters of runoff per year.

Source

UNH GRDC Composite Runoff Data.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: UNH GRDC Composite Runoff Data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Vegetation type
page.title: Vegetation type
page.description:
Different vegetation types have different abilities to reduce soil erosion, based on attributes like vegetation height, life form, rooting depth and density.

Role in models

Vegetation type is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation in reducing soil erosion.

Representation

Data are categorical, derived from land cover classes.

Source

Various national land cover datasets.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Percent tree canopy cover
page.title: Percent tree canopy cover
page.description:
Percent tree canopy cover.

Role in models

Tree canopy cover is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation in reducing soil erosion. All else being equal, we expect greater protection from soil erosion under higher tree canopy cover.

Representation

Data represent the percentage of the land surface under tree canopy cover.

Source

)2001 National Land Cover Dataset (U.S.); University of Maryland - Global Land Cover Facility (global).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: National Land Cover Dataset, University of Maryland Global Land Cover Facility.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Successional stage
page.title: Successional stage
page.description:
Forest succession stage can dictate attributes such as vegetation height, tree canopy cover, root densities, and litter and woody debris cover, all of which can potentially reduce soil erosion.

Role in models

Successional stage is used as input into a probabilistic model estimating the contribution of vegetation in reducing soil erosion. All else being equal, we expect later successional forests to provide greater protection from soil erosion.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

BLM Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project (WA/OR).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Interagency Vegetation Mapping Project.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual sediment source
page.title: Annual sediment source
page.description:
Annual soil erosion from the landscape.

Role in models

This is the output of a probabilistic model accounting for the influence of vegetation, soils, and precipitation on erosion. These data are passed to the sediment flow model, which calculates actual sediment delivered to beneficiaries, given erosion levels, the activity of sinks, and the location of beneficiaries of sedimentation or avoided sedimentation.

Representation

The data are in physical units of tons of sediment eroded per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of sediment eroded. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Reservoir presence
page.title: Reservoir presence
page.description:
Reservoirs stop the downstream movement of sediment by trapping it in the reservoir and releasing low-sediment water downstream.

Role in models

Reservoir locations enter into a probabilistic model to estimate sediment sink values. Deposition values in reservoirs are always set to high in the probabilistic model.

Representation

The data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of reservoirs.

Source

National Atlas of the United States, Major Dams of the United States (U.S.); FAO AQUASTAT (Africa); Global Database of Dams (global).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Major dams of the United States, FAO AQUASTAT, Global Database of Dams.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Stream gradient
page.title: Stream gradient
page.description:
Stream gradient helps dictate the speed of floodwater flows, causing sediment to either be deposited or remain suspended as it moves downstream.

Role in models

Stream gradient enters into a probabilistic model to estimate sediment sink values. Deposition values are assumed to be higher along low-gradient streams, where slower-flowing water promotes deposition.

Representation

The data are in physical units of degrees slope.

Source

Derived from local hydrography data and SRTM slope data.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Floodplain tree canopy cover
page.title: Floodplain tree canopy cover
page.description:
Well-vegetatated floodplains can better trap sediment by slowing the flow of floodwater and providing microtopography where sediment can be deposited.

Role in models

Floodplain tree canopy cover enters into a probabilistic model to estimate sediment sink values. Deposition values are assumed to be higher in more forested floodplains, where vegetation can better trap sediment.

Representation

Data represent the percentage of the floodplain under tree canopy cover.

Source

)2001 National Land Cover Dataset (U.S.); University of Maryland - Global Land Cover Facility (global).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: National Land Cover Dataset, University of Maryland Global Land Cover Facility.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Floodplain width
page.title: Floodplain width
page.description:
Wider floodplains can promote sediment deposition by slowing the flow of sediment-carrying floodwater.

Role in models

Floodplain width is used as input data for a probabilistic model to estimate sediment sink values. Deposition values are assumed to be higher in wide floodplains, where floodwater can spread out and move more slowly, leading to deposition.

Representation

The data are in physical units of meters of floodplain width.

Source

Derived from FEMA Q3 Flood Data (U.S.); Dartmouth Flood Observatory (global).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: FEMA Q3 Flood Data, Dartmouth Flood Observatory.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Annual sediment sink
page.title: Annual sediment sink
page.description:
The deposition of waterborne sediment in floodplains.

Role in models

This is the output of a probabilistic model accounting for the influence of floodplain characteristics on sediment deposition. These data are passed to the sediment flow model, which calculates actual sediment delivered to beneficiaries, given erosion levels, the activity of sinks, and the location of beneficiaries of sedimentation or avoided sedimentation.

Representation

The data are in physical units of tons of sediment deposited per year. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution of the amount of sediment deposited. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Floodplain extent
page.title: Floodplain extent
page.description:
The extent of the mapped or observed floodplain.

Role in models

Floodplain extents are used in the use models to identify the presence of farmland located in the flood zone. These are the beneficiaries of either beneficial sediment delievery or avoided delivery of detrimental sediment. Floodplain extents are also used in the flow models to distribute sediment across the floodplain.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing extent of the floodplain.

Source

FEMA Q3 Flood Data (U.S.); Dartmouth Flood Observatory (global).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: FEMA Q3 Flood Data, Dartmouth Flood Observatory.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Farmland
page.title: Farmland
page.description:
Farmland that can either benefit from or be harmed by sediment deposition.

Role in models

Farmland locations are intersected with floodplain extents data to map the potential beneficiaries of sediment regulation. The sediment flow model is then used to estimate actual sediment regulation values.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of farmland.

Source

Various national land cover datasets.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Deposition prone farmers
page.title: Deposition prone farmers
page.description:
Farmland located in floodplains is a beneficiary group of sediment regulation, either of avoided detrimental sediment or delivery of beneficial sediment.

Role in models

This is one beneficiary group for sediment regulation. The location of farmland susceptible to sedimentation is passed to the flow model, which calculates actual sedimentation levels, given erosion levels and the location of sinks that deposit sediment.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of floodplain farmland.

Source

Intersection of floodplain extents data and farmland cover data.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Elevation
page.title: Elevation
page.description:
Elevation above sea level.

Role in models

A digital elevation model is used along with hydrography data to route sediment-carrying water across the land surface. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which water then follows through the stream network.

Representation

The data are in physical units of meters above sea level.

Source

Global 90-m SRTM digital elevation model.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data source: Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data.
Funding: U.S. National Science Foundation.

page.name: Rivers
page.title: Rivers
page.description:
River and stream locations.

Role in models

River and stream locations, or hydrography data, are used to route sediment-carrying surface water. The flow model moves precipitation downslope using elevation data until it reaches a stream network, which water then follows through the stream network.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of rivers and streams.

Source

Digital Chart of the World; BD500 (Madagascar infrastructure dataset); Washington Department of Natural Resources.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Levees
page.title: Levees
page.description:
Levees restrict a river's flow to its channel, limiting the ability of floodwater to spread across the floodplain and deposit sediment.

Role in models

Levee location data are used in the flow model to limit the spread of floodwater across the floodplain when levees are present, eliminating the possibility of sediment deposition beyond levees.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of levees.

Source

County GIS offices (where available).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Possible sediment flow
page.title: Possible sediment flow
page.description:
*Possible flow maps* represent the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows the downstream movement of sediment when not accounting for sediment sinks (i.e., areas of deposition).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Possible sediment source
page.title: Possible sediment source
page.description:
Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity actually has the ability to reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape. Flow analysis allows us to identify which particular portion of the total source quantity is actually generating carriers that reach the users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account the result of use values, the structure of the landscape and the flow paths of the carrier, producing this *possible source map*. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the portion of the source field that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This map shows areas which, based on the flow pattern of sediment but when not accounting for sinks (i.e., depositional areas), provide sediment which reaches downstream users who either benefit from or are damaged by sediment delivery.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Possible reduced sediment deposition beneficiaries
page.title: Possible reduced sediment deposition beneficiaries
page.description:
*Possible use maps* show the locations of users on the landscape that can receive a benefit due to flow connections with a source of an ecosystem service carrier, but may or may not actually receive the carrier due to the action of sinks. For provisioning services, potential use identifies areas where it is physically possible for a benefit to be received. For preventive services, potential use identifies areas that may be damaged by a detrimental carrier if sinks do not prevent such damage.
This map shows beneficiaries who receive beneficial or detrimental sedimentation when accounting for flow paths but not sinks.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Actual sediment flow
page.title: Actual sediment flow
page.description:
The *actual flow density* map shows the flow paths that deliver actual services to humans. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
In this case, the density of actual flows represents the downstream movement of sediment when accounting for sediment sinks (i.e., areas of deposition).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Actual sediment source
page.title: Actual sediment source
page.description:
The *actual source map* shows the portion of the source map that is relevant to the provision of a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics. For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier were neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows areas which, based on the flow pattern of sediment and accounting for sinks (i.e., depositional areas), provide sediment to downstream users who either benefit from or are damaged by sediment delivery.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Actual deposition
page.title: Utilized sediment deposition
page.description:
The *actual sink map* shows the portion of the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns. For provisioning services, such sinks are responsible for reducing the benefits compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows depositional areas that undergo sedimentation, receiving upstream sediment and actively performing a sediment trapping function.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Actual reduced sediment deposition beneficiaries
page.title: Actual reduced sediment deposition beneficiaries
page.description:
The *actual use map* shows the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users located across the landscape.
This map shows beneficiaries who receive beneficial or detrimental sedimentation when accounting for flow paths and sinks.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Unutilized sediment source
page.title: Unutilized sediment source
page.description:
The *inaccessible source map* shows the flow paths that cannot deliver a service carrier to humans based on the flow routes and the source and user locations.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show areas that could provide a benefit, but do not due to a lack of flow connections to potential users. For preventive services, the flow paths show potential sources of a damaging carrier that do not impact people.
This map shows areas which, based on the flow pattern of sediment, do not provide sediment to downstream users who either benefit from or are damaged by sediment delivery.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Absorbed sediment flow
page.title: Absorbed sediment flow
page.description:
The *blocked flow map* shows the flow paths that could have delivered the service carrier to humans based on the flow routes and the source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show the loss in possible flow of beneficial services to the users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the flow paths show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows the flow of sediment that does not reach downstream beneficiaries (who benefit from either avoided detrimental sedimentation or beneficial sediment delivery).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Negated sediment source
page.title: Negated sediment source
page.description:
The *blocked source map* shows the part of the source map that had the possibility of reaching users given the location of the users and the flow dynamics, but was blocked from doing so because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but lost before it reaches the users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but was blocked by natural features.
This map shows areas which, based on the deposition occurring sinks areas, do not provide sediment to downstream users who either benefit from or are damaged by sediment delivery.
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Blocked harmful sediment
page.title: Blocked harmful sediment
page.description:
The *blocked use map* shows those users that would have been reached by the service carrier based only on the source and the flow dynamics, but were not reached because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that has not been accrued to users because of sinks; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users thanks to sink configuration.
For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and natural sink features.
This map shows beneficiaries who receive less detrimental sediment as a result of sink actions (sediment deposition).
page.see-also: The sediment regulation section of the ARIES web site
